Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XII. THE SPICERS. The Annunciation, and visit of Elizabeth to Mary. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Prologue. Angelus. Maria. Elizabeth.]

[Scene I, Nazareth: Prologue in the fore-ground.] 1. Lord God, grete meruell es to mene, Howe man was made with-outen mysse, And sette whare he sulde euer haue bene With-outen bale, bidand in blisse. And howe he lost Ã¾at comforth clene, And was putte oute fro paradys, And sithen what sorouse sor warre sene Sente vn-to hym and to al his. And howe they lay lange space In helle lokyn fro lyght, Tille god graunted Ã¾am grace Of helpe, als he hadde hyght. 2. Ãan is it nedfull for to neven, How prophettis all goddis counsailes kende, Als prophet Amos in his steuen, Lered whils he in his liffe gun lende. Deus pater disposuit salutem fieri in medio terre etce. He sais Ã¾us, god Ã¾e fadir in heuen Ordand in erthe man kynde to mende; And to grayth it with godhede euen, His sone he saide Ã¾at he suld sende. To take kynde of man-kyn In a mayden full mylde; So was many saued of syn And the foule fende be-gyled. 3. And for the feende suld so be fedd Be tyne, and to no treuth take tentt, God made Ã¾at mayden to be wedde, Or he his sone vn-to hir sentte. So was the godhede closed and cledde In wede of weddyng whare thy wente; And Ã¾at oure blysse sulde so be bredde, Ful many materes may be mente. Quoniam in semine tuo benedicentur omnes gentes &c. God hym self sayde this thynge To Abraham als hym liste, Of thy sede sall vppe sprynge Whare in folke sall be bliste. 4. To proue thes prophettes ordande [wer], Er als I say vn-to olde and yenge. He moued oure myscheues for to merr, For thus he prayed god for this thynge, Orate celi desuper, Lord, late Ã¾ou doune at thy likyng Ãe dewe to fall fro heuen so ferre, For than the erthe sall sprede and sprynge A seede Ã¾at vs sall saue, Ãat nowe in blisse are bente. Of clerkis who-so will craue, Ãus may Ã¾er-gatis be mente. 5. Ãe dewe to Ã¾e gode halygaste May be remened in mannes mynde, The erthe vnto Ã¾e mayden chaste, By-cause sho comes of erthely kynde. Ãir wise wordis ware noght wroght in waste, To waffe and wende away als wynde, For this same prophett sone in haste Saide forthermore, als folkes may fynde. Propter hoc dabit dominus ipse vobis signum &c. Loo he sais Ã¾us, god sall gyffe Here-of a syngne to see Tille all Ã¾at lely lyffe, And Ã¾is Ã¾are sygne salbe. Ecce uirgo concipiett, et pariet filium &c. 6. Loo! he sais a mayden mon Here on this molde mankynde omell, Ful clere consayue and bere a sonne, And neven his name Emanuell. His kyngdom Ã¾at euer is be-gonne, Sall never sese, but dure and dwell; On dauid sege Ã¾ore sall he wonne, His domes to deme and trueth to telle. Zelus domini faciet hoc &c. He says, luffe of oure Lorde, All Ã¾is sall ordan Ã¾anne That mennes pees and accorde To make with erthely manne. 7. More of Ã¾is maiden me meves [he], This prophett sais for oure socoure, Egredietur virga de Jesse, A wande sall brede of Jesse boure; And of Ã¾is same also sais hee, Vpponne Ã¾at wande sall springe a floure, Wher-on Ã¾e haly gast sall be, To governe it with grete honnoure. That wande meynes vntill vs Ãis mayden, even and morne, And Ã¾e floure is Jesus, Ãat of Ã¾at blyst bees borne. 8. Ãe prophet Johell, a gentill Jewe, Som-tyme has saide of Ã¾e same thyng; He likenes criste euen als he knewe, Like to Ã¾e dewe in doune commyng. Ero quasi ros et virgo Israell germinabit sicut lilium. Ãe maiden of Israell al newe He sais, sall bere one and forthe brynge, Als Ã¾e lelly floure full faire of hewe, Ãis meynes sa to olde and ?enge Ãat Ã¾e hegh haly gaste, Come oure myscheffe to mende, In marie mayden chaste, When god his sone walde sende. 9. Ãis lady is to Ã¾e lilly lyke, Ãat is by-cause of hir clene liffe, For in Ã¾is worlde was never slyke, One to be mayden, modir, and wyffe. And hir sonne kyng in heuen-ryke, Als oft es red be reasoune ryfe; And hir husband bath maistir and meke, In charite to stynte all striffe. Ãis passed all worldly witte, How god had ordand Ã¾aim Ã¾anne, In hir one to be knytte, Godhed, maydenhed, and manne. 10. Bot of Ã¾is werke grete witnes was, With forme-ffaders, all folke may tell. Whan Jacob blyst his sone Judas, He told Ã¾e tale Ã¾aim two emell; Non auferetur s[c]eptrum de Juda, Ueniat qui mittendus est. He sais Ã¾e septer sall noght passe Fra iuda lande of Israell, Or he comme Ã¾at god ordand has To be sente feendis force to fell. Et ipse erit expectacio gencium. Hym sall alle folke abyde, And stand vn-to his steuen, Ther sawes wer signified To crist goddis sone in heuen. 11. For howe he was sente, se we more, And howe god wolde his place puruay, He saide, âsonne I sall sende by-fore Myne Aungell to rede Ã¾e thy way.â Ecce mitto angelum meum ante faciem tuam qui preparabit viam tuam ante te. Of John Baptist he menyd Ã¾ore, For in erthe he was ordand ay, To warne Ã¾e folke Ã¾at wilsom wore Of Cristis comyng, and Ã¾us gon say; Ego quidem baptizo in aqua vos autem Baptizabimini spiritu sancto. âEftir me sall come nowe A man of myghtist mast, And sall baptis ?owe In the high haly gast.â 12. Ãus of cristis commyng may we see, How sainte Luke spekis in his gospell, âFro God in heuen es sent,â sais he, âAn aungell is named Gabriell To Nazareth in Galale, Where Ã¾an a mayden mylde gon dwell, Ãat with Joseph suld wedded be. Hir name is Marie,â Ã¾us gan he telle, To god his grace Ã¾an grayd, To man in Ã¾is manere, And how Ã¾e Aungell saide, Takes hede, all Ã¾at will here. [Exit Prologue. Tunc cantat angelus. 13. Ang. Hayle! Marie! full of grace and blysse, Oure lord god is with Ã¾e, And has chosen Ã¾e for his, Of all women blist mot Ã¾ou be. Maria. What maner of halsyng is Ã¾is? Ãus preuely comes to me, For in myn herte a thoght it is, Ãe tokenyng Ã¾at I here see. Tunc cantat angelus, Ne timeas Maria. 14. Ang. Ne drede Ã¾e noght, Ã¾ou mylde marie, For no-thyng Ã¾at may be-falle, For Ã¾ou has fun soueranly At god a grace ouer othir all. In chastite of thy bodye Consayue and bere a childe Ã¾ou sall, This bodword brynge I Ã¾e, for-thy His name Jesu sall Ã¾ou calle. 15. Mekill of myght Ã¾an sall he bee, He sall be God and called God sonne. Dauid sege, his fadir free, Sall God hym giffe to sytte vppon; Als kyng for euer regne sall hee, In Jacob house ay for to wonne. Of his kyngdome and dignite Shall noo man erthly knaw ne con. 16. Maria. Ãou goddis aungell, meke and mylde, Howe sulde it be, I the praye, That I sulde consayve a childe Of any man by nyght or daye. I knawe no man Ã¾at shulde haue fyled My maydenhode, the sothe to saye; With-outen will of werkis wilde, In chastite I haue ben ay. 17. Ang. The Halygast in Ã¾e sall lighte, Hegh vertue sall to Ã¾e holde, The holy birthe of the so bright, God sonne he sall be calde. Loo, Elyzabeth, Ã¾i cosyne, ne myght In elde consayue a childe for alde, Ãis is Ã¾e sexte moneth full ryght, To hir Ã¾at baran has ben talde. 18. Maria. Thou aungell, blissid messanger, Of goddis will I holde me payde, I love my lorde with herte dere, Ãe grace Ã¾at he has for me layde. Goddis handmayden, lo! me here, To his wille all redy grayd, Be done to me of all manere, Thurgh thy worde als Ã¾ou hast saide. 19. [Ang.] Now God, Ã¾at all oure hope is in, Thur[gh] the myght of Ã¾e haly gaste, Saue Ã¾e, dame, fro sak of synne, And wisse Ã¾e fro all werkis wast! [Exit Angel.]

Scene II, the house of Zacharias; Mary visits Elizabeth.] [Maria.] Elyzabeth, myn awne cosyne, Me thoght I coveyte alway mast To speke with Ã¾e of all my kynne, Therfore I comme Ã¾us in Ã¾is hast. 20. Eliz. Welcome! mylde Marie, Myne aughen cosyne so dere, Joifull woman am I, Ãat I nowe see Ã¾e here. Blissid be Ã¾ou anely Of all women in feere, And Ã¾e frute of thy body Be blissid ferre and nere. 21. Ãis is ioyfull tydyng Ãat I may nowe here see, Ãe modyr of my lord kyng, Thus-gate come to me. Sone als Ã¾e voyce of Ã¾ine haylsing Moght myn neres entre and be, Ãe childe in my wombe so yenge, Makes grete myrthe vnto Ã¾e. 22. Maria. Nowe lorde! blist be Ã¾ou ay For Ã¾e grace Ã¾ou has me lente; Lorde I lofe Ã¾e god verray, Ãe sande Ã¾ou hast me sente. I Ã¾anke Ã¾e nyght and day, And prayes with goode entente Ãou make me to thy paye, To Ã¾e my wille is wentte. 23. Eliz. Blissed be Ã¾ou grathely grayed To god thurgh chastite, Ãou trowed and helde Ã¾e payed Atte his wille for to bee. All Ã¾at to Ã¾e is saide, Fro my lorde so free, Swilke grace is for the layde, Sall be fulfilled in Ã¾e. 24. Maria. [T]o his grace I will me ta, With chastite to dele, Ãat made me Ã¾us to ga Omange his maidens fele. My saule sall louying ma Vn-to Ã¾at lorde so lele, And my gast make ioye alswa In god Ã¾at es my hele. Magnificat, [tunc cantat.
